body_content.explanation: to tune a musical instrument (= change some parts on it) again so that it produces the correct sounds when played, or to change it so that it produces higher or lower sounds than usual :
examples: Near the end the soloist had to retune her violin while the orchestra went on without her.
The band keep guitars dedicated to those tunings so they don't have to re-tune between songs.

body_content.explanation: to move the controls on a radio, television, etc. so that it can receive different programmes :
examples: The reorganization will require engineers to retune thousands of radios.
The beauty of a digital radio is that you never need to re-tune.

body_content.explanation: to make small changes to something so that it works better or in a different way:
examples: The restaurant re-tuned its menu to cater for modern tastes.
The show has been retuned for a younger, family audience.
